dataset.title: City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities, Marbled Murrelet Habitat Enhancement Experiment 2010, Cedar River Municipal Watershed, King County, WA

creator.organizationName: City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities
City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities

metadataProvider.organizationName: City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities

abstract.para: This experimental project aims to enhance nesting habitat for the marbled murrelet through active habitat restoration inn second-growth forests. The project was conducted within the Cedar River Municipal Watershed (CRMW) in Washington State, with the goal of determining if silvicultural treatments, such as creating canopy gaps and tree topping, can accelerate the growth of tree branches suitable for murrelet nesting.

The project was implemented in 2010 at a 75-acre site within CRMW. Treatments included removing surrounding trees to increase canopy openness ("gaps"), topping trees to stimulate branch growth, and combining both methods. The site was specifically chosen for its proximity to the murrelet detections in nearby old growth stands, and site suitability in terms of tree age, species composition, and manageable topography.

Data collected focused on tree growth and structure characteristics critical to murrelet nesting. A total of 48 trees received treatments, which were systematically compared to untreated controls to assess outcomes. The initial implementation confirmed logistical feasibility and budget adherence, with plans for monitoring and resampling established for the 2020s.

If successful, these techniques could be replicated across various environmental conditions to expand viable nesting habitat for the marbled murrelet, directly supporting conservation objectives outlined in the CRMW Habitat Conservation Plan.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Within Cedar River Municipal Watershed in King County Washington USA. EPSG 4326

maintenance.description: Data package will be updated when re-measurements are collected and validated. A re-measurement occurred in 2021, but I have concerns about protocol confusion and resulting data quality and want to obtain aerial photos of the topped trees to corroborate those re-measurements before publishing them. Another re-measurement may or may not occur in 2040 depending on funding.

contact.organizationName: City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities

description.para: Selected a 75-acre experimental site within the Cedar River Municipal Watershed based on suitable age (approximately 65 years old), species composition (primarily western hemlock and Douglas fir), moderate growing site class (site class 3), relatively low elevation (1,900-2,200 feet), and manageable flat topography. Marbled murrelet surveys for a different project revealed murrelet detections in nearby old growth stands approximately 1.5 miles upstream, which was an additional consideration for project location. The project site was not adjoining those old growth stands, and the project was implemented outside of the nesting season to avoid potential acoustic disturbances.

Established eight treatment blocks, each consisting of one of the following treatments: Western hemlock (gapped, topped, gapped and topped, control/no treatment), Douglas fir (gapped, topped, gapped and topped, control/no treatment).

Selected 48 dominant or co-dominant trees at intervals of approximately 180 feet along eight transects within the project site, with actual selection occurring 2-80 feet from each transect to accommodate ecological considerations and feasibility.

Treatment (gaps): Removed all competing canopy trees within a 40-foot radius around target dominant/co-dominant trees, effectively isolating each target tree within a gap. Left cut trees on-site as downed wood, deliberately cut within six feet of the ground to promote ecological diversity and slower decay rates, thus extending the ecological value of the wood. Gap treatments aimed to increase light availability, thereby maintaining or increasing branch growth, and potentially stimulating epicormic branching in Douglas fir trees.

Treatment (topping): Selected trees were topped at a bole diameter of 4-6 inches to stimulate resource redistribution and increased growth of upper branches suitable for murrelet nesting platforms. Topping was conducted by certified arborists, using angled top cuts facing north to minimize water accumulation, stimulate scarring, and reduce decay risk. Climbing and topping were conducted carefully without climbing spurs to limit tree damage and maintain overall tree health.

Measurement: The branch diameter of five branches just below the “topping site” were measured, along with tree species, tree dbh, tree height, live crown length, tree diameter at topping site, height above topping site, and the presence of moss, dwarf mistletoe, or epicormic branching on the target tree. Branch diameters were measured six inches from the tree bole. A tag was placed where the topping site would be for trees that were not topped, to allow for re-measurement of the same branches.

methodStep.instrumentation: DBH tape in inches. Laser rangefinder.

personnel.organizationName: City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities

abstract.para: The City will consider developing a monitoring and research program, in cooperation with the USFWS, to enhance potential marbled murrelet nesting habitat in selected second-growth within the watershed.

dataTable.entityDescription: Contains attribute and location data for trees included in the habitat experiment. TagNum is the primary key joining the two tables.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Unique identification number depicted on metal tag nailed to project tree
Chronological number of project tree as it was added to the project. Each tree has a unique TreeNum and TagNum. Both are retained in the data just in case.
Species of project tree
Whether or not the project tree was topped

codeDefinition.definition: Tree was topped. Upper ~20 feet of the tree was removed, where the tree bole diameter was about 4-6 inches.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Whether or not the projec tree was gapped

codeDefinition.definition: Tree was gapped. All canopy competitors (i.e. other trees) within 40 feet of the project tree were removed, leaving the single project tree in the middle of a 80 foot diameter forest gap.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Concatenated grouping code of Species-Treatment1-Treatment2

codeDefinition.definition: Douglas Fir control tree. No treatment.
Douglas Fir gapped and topped tree
Western Hemlock control tree. Not treatment.
Western Hemlock topped and gapped tree

attribute.attributeDefinition: Transect number of project trees. Used for project layout and planning purposes.
Longitude position of project tree. Units are decimal degrees in WGS84.
Latitude position of project tree. Units are decimal degrees in WGS84.

dataTable.entityDescription: Contains tree attribute and experimental treatment information for treatment and control trees for the marbled murrelet habitat enhancement project. Measurements were taken at the time of experimental treatment (creating a gap around a tree, removing part of the crown ("topping"), both those things, or nothing (control)).

attribute.attributeDefinition: Chronological number of project tree as it was added to the project. Each tree has a unique TreeNum and TagNum. Both are retained in the data just in case.
Transect number of project trees. Used for project layout and planning purposes.
Unique identification number depicted on metal tag nailed to project tree
Species of project tree
Diameter at breast height of project tree.
Diameter of tree bole at height where the tree would be topped for project treatment
Slope angle at project tree
Slope aspect at project tree
Whether or not the project tree was topped

codeDefinition.definition: Tree was topped. Upper ~20 feet of the tree was removed, where the tree bole diameter was about 4-6 inches.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Whether or not the projec tree was gapped

codeDefinition.definition: Tree was gapped. All canopy competitors (i.e. other trees) within 40 feet of the project tree were removed, leaving the single project tree in the middle of a 80 foot diameter forest gap.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Tree height in feet before treatment. Measured from the ground via laser rangefinder
Tree height above the topping site (i.e. bole length), estimated for trees that were not topped, and measured with a tape for tops that fell to the ground
Live crown length before topping, measured with laser rangefinder
unknown what this column means
Branch diameter 1 of 5 of branches measured just below the topping site, or where the topping site would be for trees not topped. Measured six inches from the tree bole.
Branch diameter 2 of 5 of branches measured just below the topping site, or where the topping site would be for trees not topped. Measured six inches from the tree bole.
Branch diameter 3 of 5 of branches measured just below the topping site, or where the topping site would be for trees not topped. Measured six inches from the tree bole.
Branch diameter 4 of 5 of branches measured just below the topping site, or where the topping site would be for trees not topped. Measured six inches from the tree bole.
Branch diameter 5 of 5 of branches measured just below the topping site, or where the topping site would be for trees not topped. Measured six inches from the tree bole.
Canopy moss presence or absence
Date when the tree was sampled
Comments noted. Typically related to treatment outcomes, tree position relative to transect, and other notable things.

otherEntity.entityDescription: As-built report detailing project background, goals, methodology, summary statistics of measurements collected during project implementation.

otherEntity.entityDescription: Research poster presented by Bill Richards, who originated the project, at the 2012 Ecological Society of America conference.
Photograph of an experiment tree. Example of a gapped tree that was not topped.
Photograph depicts a tree from the experiment that was gapped and topped, receiving both experimental treatments.
Photo depicts a tree from the experiment that was not gapped. A photo of the tree crown was not practical due to the dense nature of the stand. Stand density is evident in the photograph.
